qas.question: How do the wrestlers treat the audience?

answers.text: The audience is recognized and acknowledged by the performers as spectators

qas.question: How does the audience being acknowledged by the wrestlers impact the show?

answers.text: This leads to a high level of audience participation

qas.question: What can the audience do during a show?

answers.text: their reactions can dictate how the performance unfolds.

qas.question: What kind of conflict can arise during a show?

answers.text: Often, individual matches will be part of a longer storyline conflict between "babyfaces" (often shortened to just "faces") and "heels".

qas.question: Which of the wrestlers are the bad guys?

context: Professional wrestling shows can be considered a form of theatre in the round, with the ring, ringside area, and entryway comprising a thrust stage. However, there is a much more limited concept of a fourth wall than in most theatric performances. <a0_0>The audience is recognized and acknowledged by the performers as spectators<a0_0/> to the sporting event being portrayed, and are encouraged to interact as such. <a1_0>This leads to a high level of audience participation<a1_0/>; in fact, <a2_0>their reactions can dictate how the performance unfolds.<a2_0/> <a3_0>Often, individual matches will be part of a longer storyline conflict between "babyfaces" (often shortened to just "faces") and "heels".<a3_0/> "Faces" (the "good guys") are those whose actions are intended to encourage the audience to cheer, while <a4_0>"heels" (the "bad guys")<a4_0/> act to draw the spectators' ire.
